p: To investigate the influence of lubrication on the K-LMP and K-LCP, coconut oil calcium-based grease containing K-LMP or K-LCP after long run (3600 s) friction-wear test at 294 N was adequately diluted with petroleum ether, oleic acid and alcohol to completely remove calcium soap and coconut oil. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and SEM were used to characterise typical solid samples before and after lubrication testing. The powder XRD patterns (Supplementary Figure S9) of K-LMP and K-LCP showed that the diffraction peak positions and diffraction peak intensities are consistent with the original samples. SEM images (Supplementary Figure S10) further confirmed that neither the particle size nor the morphology of K-LMP and K-LCP changed after lubrication testing. The above characterisation results demonstrate that K-LMP and K-LCP as grease additives can remain stable under long-term working conditions.
